user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CondVarGetInfo:
```c
int32 OS_CondVarGetInfo(osal_id_t var_id, OS_condvar_prop_t *condvar_prop)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    int32               return_code;
    OS_object_token_t   token;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(condvar_prop);

    memset(condvar_prop, 0, sizeof(OS_condvar_prop_t));

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONDVAR, var_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_global_condvar_table, token);

        strncpy(condvar_prop->name, record->name_entry, sizeof(condvar_prop->name) - 1);
        condvar_prop->creator = record->creator;

        return_code = OS_CondVarGetInfo_Impl(&token, condvar_prop);

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_global_condvar_table, token);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 1.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No language extensions are evident in the fragment. The line is a normal macro invocation/assignment; this does not itself use any compiler-specific extension. (If the macro OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET were implemented using a compiler extension — e.g. GCC statement-expressions ({ ... }), __typeof__, or other documented compiler-specific features — that macro definition would violate Rule 1.2. To be certain, inspect the definition of OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET for any compiler-specific constructs.)
